title: Discover the Healing Hot Springs and Ecotourism of the New Valley in Egypt
text:
2024-02-15 23:00:00
The winter of the New Valley is unlike any other place in Egypt because the desert governorate is characterized by a warm atmosphere, bright sun, and a pure and ideal environment for ecotourism pioneers, in addition to its uniqueness in the spread of hot wells, which contain many therapeutic elements and compounds that contribute to recovery programs and treatment of joint diseases, skin diseases, rheumatism, and other diseases. Rheumatoid arthritis, spinal problems, and those undergoing weight loss programs. These wells are distinguished by their hot water, which reaches a temperature of 43 degrees Celsius. According to laboratory analyzes conducted by health affairs in the governorate, they confirmed that the water from these wells contains many mineral elements that treat these diseases.
The center of Dakhla occupies the forefront in terms of demand for medical tourism enthusiasts at the governorate level, because it contains more than 500 hot wells, the most important of which is located three kilometers from the city of Mut, the capital of Dakhla. It is a group of self-flowing wells, emanating from a depth of 1224 meters, and tourism development work has begun for those. The wells were established during the reign of Dr. Abdel Moneim Hanafi, head of the Dakhla Center in 1982. Two swimming pools were built next to these wells, one for adults and the other for children. Sleeping rooms were also set up for visitors to the area to stay in. It was also provided with a restaurant and cafeteria. The area is connected by a paved road, and is located on the road leading to tourist attractions.
New Valley wells, especially sulfur wells, have become a major factor in treating osteoarthritis, fibromyalgia, neuritis and the resulting pain, paralysis, weakness of the limbs, neurological and psychological diseases, chronic gout (kings disease), and respiratory diseases such as chronic sinusitis, bronchitis, and bronchial asthma. Chronic and skin diseases such as scabies, eczema, acne, psoriasis, joint stiffness, healed fractures accompanied by complications of faulty healing, chronic insufficiency of the arterial circulation of the extremities, and excessive and morbid obesity.
The system of developing and raising the efficiency of government tourist hot wells was completed after Major General Dr. Muhammad Al-Zamlot took office, the current governor of the region. A conference was hosted on marketing and activating medical and hospital tourism in the New Valley in the presence of a delegation of European and Egyptian doctors. The development work included raising the efficiency of the Bir Jannah area in Kharga and the Bir al-Jabal area. Dakhla, because of its hot water and therapeutic sand, and its ability to treat incurable diseases.
The efficiency of the “Mot 3” tourist wells in the center was also increased, and the rooms and swimming pool were developed and equipped at a high level. To maximize the benefit and provide an attraction for tourists, given that the “Mout 3” wells flow with hot sulfurous water whose temperature ranges from 45 to 70 degrees Celsius, with the aim of raising the rates of medical and hospital tourism and exploiting the hot wells that characterize the Dakhla region alone.
There are also a number of hot wells spread in the center of Kharga, including Bulaq wells, which are about 28 km away from the city of Kharga to the south. They are self-flowing wells that originate from a depth of up to a thousand meters, and their temperature is 28 degrees Celsius, surrounded by large areas of greenery. Laboratory analysis has proven Its water contains mineral elements that have many therapeutic benefits, and there are soft sand dunes nearby that are used to treat joint diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and cartilage pain.
The efficiency and development of the Nasser Tourist Camp and Well in Nasser Al-Thawra village in the center of Al-Kharga was also raised, which includes tourist camps and groundwater wells and is surrounded by palm trees, domes and ornamental trees and has been equipped for recreational trips since the sixties. It was named Nasser Well after the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser, in light of the establishment of New villages in the governorate by the Desert Reconstruction Authority in the sixties.
